name: Tree of Heaven
reasonToAvoid: Highly invasive; spreads aggressively via seeds and root sprouts; releases allelopathic chemicals that suppress native plants; foul odor; weak wood prone to breakage; host for spotted lanternfly
notes: Banned or restricted in many states; do not plant under any circumstances

name: Bradford Pear
reasonToAvoid: Invasive escapee from cultivars; weak branch structure leads to storm damage; foul-smelling flowers; thorny wild forms; overplanted and ecologically useless
notes: All Callery pear cultivars can cross-pollinate and produce invasive seedlings

name: Silver Maple
reasonToAvoid: Weak wood and shallow roots cause sidewalk heaving and frequent branch failure; short-lived; aggressive surface roots; pest magnet (aphids, scale)
notes: Native but ecologically and structurally problematic in urban settings

name: Siberian Elm
reasonToAvoid: Highly invasive; weak brittle wood; short-lived; heavy seeder; pest and disease prone; low-value wood
notes: Often planted as a fast screen but escapes and outcompetes natives

name: Black Locust
reasonToAvoid: Invasive in many regions; sharp thorns; suckers aggressively; short-lived; wood valuable but tree is high-maintenance; toxic seeds and bark
soil: Poor to fertile, dry to moist
notes: Native in Appalachia but invasive elsewhere; forms dense thickets

name: Princess Tree
reasonToAvoid: Extremely invasive; lightweight wood but spreads via millions of wind-dispersed seeds; weak wood; hollow trunks; dies back in cold winters
notes: One of the fastest-growing trees; banned in Connecticut and other areas

name: White Mulberry
reasonToAvoid: Highly invasive; hybridizes with native red mulberry; fruits stain pavement; pollen is highly allergenic; supports silkworms but harms ecosystems
notes: Competes with and genetically pollutes native red mulberry populations

name: Norway Maple
reasonToAvoid: Invasive; dense shade suppresses understory; shallow roots compete aggressively; overplanted in urban areas; yellow fall color but low wildlife value
notes: Banned in Massachusetts and New Hampshire; outcompetes sugar maple

name: Mimosa
reasonToAvoid: Invasive in the South; short-lived; weak wood; messy flowers and pods; attracts webworms; surface roots; dies in cold snaps
notes: Pretty pink flowers but high-maintenance and ecologically disruptive

name: Russian Olive
reasonToAvoid: Invasive in western U.S.; thorny; nitrogen-fixing alters soil; dense thickets crowd out natives; low wildlife value despite berries
notes: Banned in Colorado, New Mexico; forms impenetrable thickets

name: Autumn Olive
reasonToAvoid: Highly invasive; nitrogen-fixing; dense growth; millions of bird-dispersed seeds; outcompetes natives in fields and forests
notes: Banned in several states; berries eaten by birds but spread aggressively

name: Chinese Tallow (Popcorn Tree)
reasonToAvoid: Extremely invasive in the Southeast; rapid spread via seeds and suckers; toxic sap; colorful fall foliage but destroys wetlands and grasslands
notes: One of the worst invasives in Louisiana, Texas, and Florida

name: Empress Tree
reasonToAvoid: Same as Princess Tree; extremely fast-growing; weak wood; massive seed production; dies back in Zone 5 winters
notes: Often sold as 'Royal Empress' â€” avoid all marketing names

name: Willow (non-native hybrids)
reasonToAvoid: Aggressive roots clog pipes and drains; weak wood; short-lived; high water use; pest-prone
notes: Native willows are fine; avoid hybrid basket willows and non-native species

name: Lombardy Poplar
reasonToAvoid: Very short-lived (15-30 years); weak wood; canker disease; aggressive roots; male clones produce cottony fluff
notes: Often planted for quick screen but fails quickly and looks bad
